element_texts.text:
Resume´ ____ 
A Winter Campaign is a terrible ordeal for troops, but it is really the most effective against Indians, who cannot stand cold so well as whites, nor can they travel rapidly with their half famished skeletons of horses

Compelled to move their village not less than twice to leave the game region of the Rosebud in which they had pitched their winter camp and to take refuge in the barren inhospitable and comparatively gameless bad lands of

Take it in its entirely our Campaign has been a marked success 
The Cheyenne have received a blow such as they have never had before, & from which they will not soon recover. While the hostile Sioux leader Crazy Horse has been
has not been so evidently successful as it might have been and while the facts are fresh in my mind I wish I put on record what in my opinion was the cause of the comparative failure

the Little Missouri 
They have learned by sad experience that at no time & in no place are they safe from the pursuit of the troops - 
Premising this it must yet be conceded that the Campaign

time & again among  the Indians & holding intercourse with them - 
Among Indians eloquence is a great power. All their instruction must necessarily be oral -  
Manner also has influence Genl C. has the worst manner I ever saw. He has generally very little

Genl Crook has a most wonderful knowledge of the Indian character & this knowledge gives him a power over them which I have never before seen possessed by any one - nor can I for the life of me understand it even after seeing him

for a delinquency than like a general comdy an army. 

 In spite of all this there is no shadow of a doubt as to the high extrication in which he is held by the Indians 
 He is a good strategist, & has wonderful tenacity of purpose, will & pluck & is entirely careless of

to say at any "talk" & that little is said in a few words his eyes downcast, his hands in the pockets of his old gray pants - voice low & hesitating - & in all respects he looks & acts far more like a schoolboy trying to fabricate an excuse

is a problem which to him has no solution.

 His ignorance of such things is remarkable & painful. It is even ludicrous for he carries it to such an extent as to regard with the most profound admiration any man who evinces even a moderate ability in this direction.
 He must be fully

personal discomfort

 He lacks but one thing to be a very great man - that is Administrative ability -
 He can decide how many & what troops to take into the field with him, but there his power ends. How to fit them out & care for them afterwards

This would be admirable did he only get hold of first class men, but though a fair judge of human nature, he  yet in the nature of things sometimes gets a man unequal to his work.

 The success of an expedition depends more on the administrative ability of the staff than the genius? of the

aware of his own deficiency in this respect for having selected  Officers to do this work for him. He never interferes in any way by order or suggestion & when he gets hold of a man who does tolerably well. He can never advise him sufficiently or praise him enough

Genl C. had not yet succeeded in divesting himself of a certain contempt for - or rather an undervaluing of the Infantry arm.

 When he was about starting on the Rosebud Campaign I said "Genl I wish you would take me & 6 or 8 Cos of the Regt. with you" - "Why what" replied he "Could I do

General & this is more true in Indians, than in Civilized warfare - for in the former each army or active force must depend entirely on itself for every thing on the purely military organization of our winter expedition I have no comments to make except that that at its start

I do expect to take a couple of Comps as escort for the wagon train". 

 Well Genel" I said "you of course will do as you please but the very best campaign ever made against Indians in this country were made by Infantry. Let me have the management of the men for the first three weeks & after

with Infantry against Indians? Every thing I said "that you can do with cavalry except perhaps dash in & capture stock - but that inability will be more than compensated by the bitter & unclearfighting they will do"

 "Well" he answered "I dont think Infantry any account against Indians though

of Infantry against Indians --

 Long after this - & after the battle of the Rosebud I asked him rather to his surprise "if" he did not think of me during that battle? He laughed at the recollection & said "Well Dodge when my Cavalry got scattered all over creation & I

that I will guarantee to march just as far & as long as the Cavy - to run down the Indian stock - provided only that you keep me supplied with rations" --

It was of no use - He couldn't be talked into any opinion of the staying qualities

while I - though not there know that it was lost for lack of Infantry - 

 However Mackenzies affair cured him of all that Cavalry foolishness & he will never again go out with a preponderating Cavalry force. 
 His ideas in regard to the use of a large force of friendly Indians were

could not get it together or to obey orders, I did wish for a few companies of the Old Regt. However even yet he was not cured of his prejudice for he thinks to this day that the Battle of Rosebud was lost through the neglect & indisposition of some of the Cavy Officers to do their duty.

all the supplies for his expedition had to be collected & forwarded by the Chiefs of Staff who were in Omaha - with these Officers he never once communicated for nearly eight months - They knew nothing of the force he intended to take with him of the time he expected to be out - nor even of the point which was to be

admirable & carried out with great ability -- His management of the troops was sufficiently good - except where an improvement would have brought him in collision with one of his Staff - But having said this I have given him all the credit I can & I now have to speak of his deficiencies --

accumulated very large supplies at three different places. Fetterman - Laramie - & Red Cloud - & for each of timely information the supply of forage at Fort Fetterman was never sufficient - 

  When I left to join Crook Bob Williams implored me to write to him by every mail & give him all the information I could

his base of supplies -

 His own field staff issued orders to Companies in various parts of the Dept to join him, & it was only from these orders that the Chiefs of Staff were enabled to guess how many troops he had & where he would start from - As it was they were forced, in order to be surely right to

with the single exception of the Quarter Master.

 This was Capt Fury, a regular q.m. an industrious energetic hard-working man. A gentleman in manners & education & with the disposition to be a good officer. He did the very best he could but he did not know how to do. Consequently we all suffered & the Campaign was a failure -

pick up, as to how many men & animals - how long we would be out & where we expected to go.

 "For" said he "we are now working entirely in the dark & by guess & any item you may give us, may be of great service to us & to you" --
  The field staff of the expedition was excellent

forage for 30 days, & yet had ample wagons for all the extra qr mr things iron horse shoes etc etc. that were necessary --

 Instead of this we never had at any time more than 15 days rations & ½ forage for the same time 
 Consequently we were never in condition to pull away from our base for more than a week

Fury had a train of over 250 wagons & 300 pack mules. The fighting force of the Comd was about 1650 men. The non combattants swelled the number of mouths to feed to about 2,000. 

  With the means of transfer at our disposal we should have taken 40 days rations for the whole Comd & ½

wagon train, that it could only haul less than half its capacity.

 Before we left Ft Fetterman the troops had been reduced to 3 blankets per man - a common tent to every 4 & a Sibbley Stove to every 8 men. 
 When the wagons were sent to the Cos to be loaded up it was found that each teamster had a roll of bedding larger than any Officer of the Comd - while every

at a time - when we left Fetterman we had 62 days rations with us or at that base but our supply of forage was short all the time - most of the rations left at Fetterman were sent to Reno for us so that at all times we had an ample supply at the latter place -

 Now we will see where the trouble was with the

(none of the troops were allowed them) A unclear chest with plates etc - as many boxes, barrels etc of supplies as they chose to carry - & an extra man to cook for them - who of course had his extra allowance of baggage

 The consequence was that the 300 teamsters wagon masters & cooks had more actual weight & bulk of baggage than all the

3d or 4th wagon was half full of utensils of all sorts - It soon transpired that each 2 wagon Masters (& there were about a dozen) had a wall tent Sibbley Stove & bedding ad lib. Each 4 teamsters had a wall tent & Sibley Stove - Each 8 teamsters had an extra wall tent a huge 4 or 6 plate cooking stove

& then disappear to be seen no more by any of the troops until such time as it suited them to put in an appearance in the morning. All went off to the general train to sleep & eat. It seems almost incredible, yet I state it as a face; that on many occasions my rear guard had to remain

Officers & men of the whole fighting force, 1650 men, put together --

 Nor was this all - The teamsters were under no sort of discipline & did just as they pleased. Getting into Camp late - they would unhitch the mules tie them to the tongue throw a little corn into the feed bags

ashamed of myself - 
But not unfrequently my men would get into camp by 2 or 3 pm & have to wait in the snow until long after dark without shelter or food - & all because the teamsters were too lazy to get up in the morning - It was a most infernal outrage & would not have been tolerated an instant by any

in camp until half past 9 or 10 Oclk am, waiting for the teamsters to hitch the mules to the wagons which had been loaded & ready to move since half past 6 am. This condition of affairs was intolerable & I quarrelled with  Fury & with Genl Crook about it until I felt like a common scold & was

& found Genl C & staff around a camp fire -

 I was very angry & went after the Genl strong - I told him that it was an outrage on my men - on human nature & demanded that some steps be taken to remedy the evil - He looked at me in a helpless sort of way for a moment then walked away without a word. I then went for the staff all of

Comdy officer that I know of except Genl Crook.

 On Christmas day the mercury was frozen in the bulb. My Comd got off in good season 6.30. Some of the wagons not being hitched up I waited until 9.30 am then left in disgust - I arrived in camp after a march of over twenty miles.

here & let them go

 The clerk subsided & Mackenzie who was by hooked his arm with mine & led me over to his tent & gave me a drink.
 "I think" said he "you are too hard on Fury. He does the best he can" - 
 "Admitted" I replied "but that best leads to suffering of my men & it is time somebody was put

whom held their peace - At last Fury's Chief Clerk standing near said, "It cant be helped Colonel, the teamsters have a ring & if we were to discharge one, a hundred would go "Well let them go" I said "I will give you a better man in the place of every scoundrel who leaves - put them off in the prairie

Mackenzie giving it to poor Fury worse than I had ever done - so hard was he indeed that he afterwards apologised  to me & said he was sorry he had said so many mean things to Fury  ---

Another result of this condition of affairs

in his place who can do better than Fury's best" -

"You have your own unclear & your train is under your own control. The Genl will not allow me to have control of mine -- My men suffer yours dont, & there is all the difference" -
 The very next night I happened to walk over 

-

The order was obeyed by turning the mules loose & driving them off some distance from camp

 Then all the teamsters (who should have remained with the mules) came back & went to bed -
 The consequence was that next morning the mules were scattered for miles & took hours

was that the teamsters took no sort of care of their mules - In the whole trip. though out & among the wagons at all hours. I never saw a mule curried or a wagon greased --

 Once or twice orders were given to herd the mules at night -

care of we ought to have lost none - for our marches were short & by no means continuous.

 In the whole two months we marched but little over 400 miles -- There were however very many nearly broken down & abandoned & this result was not due to hard work but simply a party to neglect -- unclear Trout

to find & collect together -

 This was done only a very few times & the poor mules as a rule had nothing whatever to eat except a pint or two of corn.
 Of course they were soon starved out & broken down. Had the mules been properly taken
the failure of the Expedition -- for had we been supplied with as much rations & forage as we could have carried we could have marched three times as far & probably struck Crazy Horse

been Quarter Master of that Comd we would not have lost a half dozen mules all told --

 The lack of knowledge & management in the qrmr entailed unnecessary suffering on the men lost many mules to the Govt & caused
